title: Trust in the Giving
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock sat on his porch every morning, watching the sunrise paint the sky with hues of orange and gold. He wasn't watching the sunrise so much as he was waiting. Waiting for the mailman, waiting for a phone call, waiting for… something. He couldn’t quite name it anymore. His family had moved away years ago, and the silence of his small house often echoed with unspoken yearnings.

One particularly crisp morning, a young girl named Lily stopped by. She was selling cookies for her school fundraiser, but Hemlock noticed the downcast look in her eyes. He bought a box, more out of sympathy than hunger. As she handed him the cookies, she confessed that she was worried about her upcoming math test. "I just don't understand any of it," she sighed.

Hemlock, a retired math teacher, perked up. He hadn't used his teaching skills in years. He invited Lily to sit with him and, using simple terms and diagrams in the sand with a stick, he patiently explained the concepts. Lily's face lit up as she grasped the material. For the next few days, Lily visited Hemlock on his porch, not just for math lessons, but also for stories and companionship. Hemlock, in turn, found himself looking forward to these interactions, his porch no longer a place of waiting, but a place of connection.

Sometimes, trust isn't about grand gestures or monumental leaps of faith. It's about showing up, being present, and offering what we have, even when we feel like we have little to give. Hemlock trusted that even in his solitude, he had something valuable to offer. Lily trusted that even a stranger could provide guidance and support. And in that shared trust, both found unexpected blessings.
image_description: A weathered, wooden porch of a small house at sunrise with an old man and a young girl sitting together, diagrams drawn in the sand at their feet.
insights: This story illustrates a core aspect of trust: its reciprocal nature. Proverbs 3:5-6 encourages us to 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways submit to him, and he will make your paths straight.' But trust isn’t solely about believing in God; it’s also about trusting in the opportunities He places before us to serve and connect with others. Just as God provides, we too are called to be providers of support and kindness, trusting that in doing so, we are fulfilling His purpose.
prayer: Heavenly Father, help us to see the opportunities for connection and service that surround us each day. Remind us that even in our own perceived limitations, we have something valuable to offer. Grant us the courage to step out of our comfort zones and trust in Your guidance, knowing that in serving others, we are serving You. Open our hearts to the needs of those around us and empower us to be instruments of Your love and grace. Amen.
reflection: Where in your life are you being called to step out in trust? What skills or experiences do you possess that could benefit someone else? How can you cultivate a greater awareness of the needs of those around you and be more open to opportunities for service?
